instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
no visible water dmg / corrosion
ppbus 12.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 2.9v ??
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> : 1.2v ??
pp1v05 : 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> : 5v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 0v
there's a bit of high pitched noise around <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> or its back near smc, i couldnt pin point the exact noise
I have tried replacing <CHIP>U2700</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7780</CHIP>..
I tried replacing component where the various pulled down rail gather, but still dead
any advice ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 0v"
Remove first <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
If still low, start removing <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>/4/5/6 and <RESISTOR>R7901</RESISTOR>, one by one.
Keep in place <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7966</RESISTOR> pulled and fan spin, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 2.6v, VCORE 1.1v, but still no usb activity, fan start to spin fast after a while, pch doesnt feel warm enough to indicate that its working
should i placed back resistor <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>-5 ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
Solder back the other resistor and keep out <RESISTOR>R7966</RESISTOR> (for the moment).
Do you get 1.8V at L7720?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
okay, i can't put back rr7964, 63 and 66, or i will lose fan spin..
1v at l7720.. should be 1.8v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulled down because you have problems on some power rails.
You must fix these problems to continue.

Both <SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL> come from <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, which has incorrect level.
First check diode mode to ground on this line.
And post voltages for <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR>/30.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
I meant <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR>, sorry.
Fix <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>; check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

Check your work and be sure to use original 45/60W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
Something went wrong with SMC reballing, or other thing.
You've lost the voltages mentioned on first post.
So check and re-check your work...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is high and still no <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, you have SMC problem; note on page 62.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> is good.
You may need to replace SMC...

i say i have <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> at above msg..
<RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> guud 100k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead
threads.message:
Ooops, I missed that sorry.

You had S3, even S0 voltages.
Something happened in the process repair, if you lost all them.
If only you worked on the board since then, re-check your job.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is pulled up inside PCH.
SMC can only pull it down, via <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>; and is not the case now.
Probably PCH has been affected by heat.
Reheat using quality flux, trying to burn eventually accumulated crap.

Check again RTC signals.
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>  looks very close to lower limit...
